title: Fitting BICROS to a Patient with Long-Standing Unilateral Hearing Loss
chief_complaint: I have noticed a decline in hearing in my left ear and have been having greater difficulty communicating in the last year. I am interested in hearing assistive devices to make it easier to communicate.

problem_summary.onset: Right ear hearing loss occurred 15 years ago following surgery. Left ear hearing loss is a recent decline.
problem_summary.course: Right ear is stable (anacusis); Left ear is progressive/declining.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral asymmetric (Right single-sided deafness; Left high-frequency loss).
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus in the left ear (not bothersome), occasional pressure in the right ear.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Previously functioned well with positioning strategies, but recent decline in the better ear has made communication difficult.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Highly motivated for amplification; interested in devices to improve communication but wishes to avoid surgery or dental work.

history.present_illness: Patient lost all hearing in right ear 15 years ago post-acoustic neuroma removal. Recently noticed decline in left ear.
history.otologic_history: Right acoustic tumor removal ~15 years ago. Occasional pressure in right ear.
history.medical_psych_history: Denies dizziness or familial history of hearing loss.
history.prior_management: Active in acoustic tumor support group. Uses behavioral strategies (asking people to sit on left side).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: No measurable hearing (anacusis). Left ear: Slight SNHL at 250 Hz, normal 500-2000 Hz, sloping to moderate SNHL at 6000-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear shows excellent word recognition. Right ear had no response to spondees.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal middle ear function bilaterally (Type A).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsi/contra absent. Left ipsi normal 500-4000 Hz. Left contra present at 1000 Hz, elevated/absent at other frequencies.

history.present_illness: Follow-up for device selection and fitting.
history.prior_management: Discussed TransEar, AOIS, SoundBite, and BICROS. Patient rejected surgical/dental options and deep-fit molds.

tests.name: Real-ear measurements (REM)
tests.key_findings: Verified fit of Phonak Audeo S Smart III (Left) using NAL-NL1 targets. Measurements showed appropriate gain and smooth frequency response.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis
tests.key_findings: Transparency verification of the CROS transmitter. Output with transmitter ON was similar to hearing aid alone, confirming transparency.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with long-standing single-sided deafness in the right ear and a recently developed mild-to-moderate high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss in the left ear. Speech recognition remains excellent in the better (left) ear. Due to the hearing loss in the better ear, a BICROS solution was selected to provide amplification for the left ear while routing signals from the right side.
counseling_points: The BICROS system will pick up sound from your right side and send it to your left ear, but it does not restore hearing in the right ear.
You will still have difficulty telling where sounds are coming from (localization) because you are hearing everything in one ear.
In noisy situations, noise from the right side will be sent to your left ear, which can sometimes be distracting, though the device has noise reduction features.
Since you have hearing loss in your 'good' ear, the device will also amplify sounds to help you hear high-pitched speech clearly on that side.
notes_for_actor: You are comfortable with your long-standing single-sided deafness and have adapted well socially (e.g., asking people to sit on your good side).
Your main concern is the NEW decline in your 'good' ear, which is making your old coping strategies less effective.
You are resistant to surgical options (BAHA/AOIS) or devices requiring dental work (SoundBite).
You are practical and articulate about your communication needs.
